SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS

4 M.S.C. 1 § 1101The term "Residential Property" shall refer to:ACTIVE
24
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1101(a)(a) Any property zoned by Central Authority to serve residential or housing-occupancy purposes.ACTIVE
25
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1102The term "Property Owner" shall refer to:ACTIVE
26
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1102(a)(a) Any individual holding sole property rights to, or an active lease on, any residential property.ACTIVE
27
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1103The term “Resident” shall refer to:ACTIVE
28
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1103(a)(a) Any authorized or whitelisted user of a Residential Property. ACTIVE
29
30
SUBCHAPTER II. HOUSING REGULATIONS
31
32
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1201All Residential property, except Military Housing, shall remain outside the ownership, control, or management of the State of Mayflower. The State of Mayflower shall have no authority to acquire, lease, manage or allocate any Residential Property. The State shall make no effort to purchase or otherwise obtain Residential Property, and any such property currently held by the State, exempting Military Housing, shall be divested within a reasonable time as provided by law.ACTIVE
33
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1202No individual shall own, either directly or through alternative accounts, more then one Residential Property.ACTIVE
34
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1202(a)(a) Violation of this section is a violation of 1 M.S.C. § 1404 "Unfair Housing Practices"ACTIVE
35
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1203The State of Mayflower shall be the Property Owner of all unoccupied Military Housing.ACTIVE
36
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1203(a)(a) Any active serviceman of the Mayflower National Guard may submit a request to the Adjutant General, or his designee, to purchase a Military Home for an agreed upon amount of time.ACTIVE
37
4 M.S.C. 1 § 1203(b)(b) The Adjutant General of the Mayflower National Guard, or his designee, shall make an effort to house any unhoused active serviceman in unoccupied Military Housing.ACTIVE

CHAPTER II. BUSINESS AND COMMERCE REGULATION
40
41

SUBCHAPTER I. TYPES OF BUSINESSES
43
44
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2101The term "Sole Proprietorship" shall refer to:REPEALED
45
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2101(a)(a) A business entity owned by one single person who holds all power and decision making authority, and is responsible for the entity's financial obligations and legal liabilities.REPEALED
46
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2102The term "Partnership" shall refer to:REPEALED
47
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2102(a)(a) A business entity owned by two or more people who jointly hold all power and decision making authority, and are jointly responsible for the entity's financial obligations and legal liabilities.REPEALED
48
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2103The term “Corporation” shall refer to:REPEALED
49
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2103(a)(a) A business entity owned by one or more shareholders who shall also carry the burden of its financial obligations and legal liabilities. Government of a corporation shall be through its articles of incorporation as filed.REPEALED
50
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2103(a)(i)(i) Corporations shall have the ability to issue stock to raise capital.REPEALED
51
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2103(a)(ii)(iii) Corporations shall have regular shareholder meetings if it issues stock.REPEALED
52
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2104A registered business entity is a legal entity which can enter into binding agreements, sue, or be sued.REPEALED
53
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2105The term "Cooperative" shall refer to:REPEALED
54
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2105(a)(a) A business entity jointly owned and democratically controlled by its members. Business operations are controlled by a Board of Directors elected by general membership vote, who shall carry the burden of its financial obligations and legal liabilities. A cooperative is a type of corporation and its government shall be through its articles of incorporation as filed.REPEALED
55
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2106The term "Joint Venture" shall refer to:REPEALED
56
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2106(a)(a) A business entity in which two or more parties, who shall carry the burden of its financial obligations and legal liabilities, agree to pool their resources to accomplish a specific task or project. Joint ventures can be formed as separate legal entities or as contractual agreements between the parties involved.REPEALED
57
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2107A business may further be classified, in addition to one of the preceding classifications, as a non-profit organization, which shall operate primarily for a purpose other than making profit.REPEALED
58
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2108Sole proprietorships, partnerships, and joint ventures formed by contract are not legally separate entities from their responsible persons. Corporations and cooperatives are legally separate entities from their responsible persons, and are granted personhood under law.REPEALED
59
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2109The term “Freelance” shall refer to a business owned, operated, and managed by an individual who provides services independently, typically on a part-time or per-project basis, without long-term commitments to a single employer.REPEALED
60
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2110The term “Non-profit” shall refer to a business that exists to further a social cause and/or provide a public benefit where all revenue must go back into the non-profit or to its operations. A non-profit designation shall be a secondary designation to any of the business types above, and will exempt said non-profit from any tax.REPEALED

SUBCHAPTER II. BUSINESS OPERATION
63
64
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2201No person shall operate a business without a proper license from the Department of State.ACTIVE
65
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2202No business entity shall operate in a manner inconsistent with regulations promulgated by the Secretary of State in accordance with this Section.ACTIVE
66
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2202(a)(a) Regulations applied to any business entity promulgated by the Secretary of State in accordance with this act shall be created and enforced in a manner that ensures they do not unduly obstruct or excessively restrict business operations, thereby maintaining a balance between regulatory compliance and the ability of businesses to operate effectively and efficiently.ACTIVE
67
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2203The Secretary of State shall ensure that all documents and information prerequisite is provided on the registration.ACTIVE
68
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2204There shall be a form, known as the “Application for Articles of Organization” that shall be publicly available by the Department of State.ACTIVE
69
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205The Secretary of State shall refuse to file an articles of incorporation if it does not meet the following standards: ACTIVE
70
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205(a)(a) The name of the corporation is clearly typed and designated as such.ACTIVE
71
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205(b)(b) It must contain an initial appointment of the board of directors.ACTIVE
72
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205(c)(c) It must contain the number of authorized shares and who the shares are distributed to.ACTIVE
73
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205(d)(d) The name of the incorporator is clearly typed and designated as such.ACTIVE
74
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2205(e)(e) It must contain an attached set of bylaws which shall dictate the appointment of the board of directors and the further apportionment or sale of shares.ACTIVE
75
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2206The Secretary of State shall refuse to file an articles of general partnership if it does not meet the following standards:ACTIVE
76
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2206(a)(a) The name of the general partnership is clearly typed and designated as such.ACTIVE
77
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2206(b)(b) The initial partners.ACTIVE
78
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2206(c)(c) Authorization for a majority of partners to modify the general partnership including the admittance or expulsion of partners.ACTIVE
79
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2206(d)(d) The designation and appointment of a managing partner.ACTIVE
80

SUBCHAPTER III. TRADEMARKS
82
83
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2301The Secretary of State shall examine trademark applications to ensure compliance with the requirements set forth in this act, in addition to any additional requirements that the Secretary of State deems necessary. ACTIVE
84
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2302Upon determination that a trademark meets all necessary criteria, including distinctiveness and non-conflict with any existing trademarks, the Secretary of State shall approve the registration.ACTIVE
85
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2303Once a trademark has been registered with the Department of State with the approval of the Secretary of State, no other person or business entity may use the trademark unless permitted by the person or business entity who owns the rights to the trademark.ACTIVE
86
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2304The Secretary of State is required to maintain a public registry of trademarks in use. This registry shall include information regarding:ACTIVE
87
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2304(a)(a) The registered trademark;ACTIVE
88
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2304(b)(b) The owner; andACTIVE
89
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2304(c)(c) The goods or services associated with each trademark.ACTIVE
90
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2305Owners of registered trademarks shall be required to renew their trademark registrations periodically, as prescribed by the Secretary of State.ACTIVE
91
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2306If a registered trademark is revoked for any reason, including but not limited to non-renewal or infringement, the public shall once again be permitted to use the trademark.ACTIVE
92
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2307No person or business entity shall use a trademark without the explicit permission, in writing, from the registered owner of the trademark.ACTIVE
93
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2307(a)(a) Violation of this section shall be a civil tort referred to as as "Civil Trademark Infringement" punishable by declaratory judgement removing the use of said trademarks and punitive damages up to $3000.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER IV. ENFORCEMENT
96
97
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2401Any person or business entity who contravenes any provision of this Section shall, in addition to any other penalty or punishment to which the person or business entity may be liable to, be subject to the following penalties upon conviction:ACTIVE
98
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2401(a)(a) In the case of a business entity, a fine not exceeding ten thousand dollars.ACTIVE
99
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2401(b)(b) In the case of an individual, the crime of “Unlawful Operation of a Business”, or a fine not exceeding two thousand dollars, or both.ACTIVE

101
SUBCHAPTER V. DECEPTIVE AND UNFAIR TRADE PRACTICES
102
103
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2501PURPOSES; RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. The provisions of this part shall be construed liberally to promote the following policies:ACTIVE
104
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2501(a)(a) To simplify, clarify, and modernize the law governing consumer protection, unfair methods of competition, and unconscionable, deceptive, and unfair trade practices.ACTIVE
105
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2501(b)(b) To protect the consuming public and legitimate business enterprises from those who engage in unfair methods of competition, or unconscionable, deceptive, or unfair acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce.ACTIVE
106
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502DEFINITIONS. As used in this subchapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the term:ACTIVE
107
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(a)(a) "Final judgment" means a judgment, including any supporting opinion, that determines the rights of the parties and concerning which appellate remedies have been exhausted or the time for appeal has expired.ACTIVE
108
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(b)(b) "Enforcing authority" means the Department of Justice.ACTIVE
109
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(c)(c) "Violation of this part" means any violation of this act or the rules adopted under this act, and may be based upon any law, statute, rule, regulation, or ordinance which proscribes unfair methods of competition, or unfair, deceptive, or unconscionable acts or practices.ACTIVE
110
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(d)(d) "Department" means the Department of Justice.ACTIVE
111
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(e)(e) "Order" means a cease and desist order issued by the enforcing authority.ACTIVE
112
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(f)(f) "Interested party or person" means any person affected by a violation of this part or any person affected by an order of the enforcing authority.ACTIVE
113
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(g)(g) "Consumer" means an individual; business; firm; association; joint venture; partnership; trust; business trust; syndicate; fiduciary; corporation; any commercial entity, however denominated; or any other group or combination.ACTIVE
114
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(h)(h) "Trade or commerce" means the advertising, soliciting, providing, offering, or distributing, whether by sale, rental, or otherwise, of any good or service, or any property, whether tangible or intangible, or any other article, commodity, or thing of value, wherever situated. "Trade or commerce" shall include the conduct of any trade or commerce, however denominated, including any nonprofit or not-for-profit person or activity.ACTIVE
115
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2502(i)(i) "Thing of value" may include, without limitation, any moneys, donation, membership, credential, certificate, prize, award, benefit, license, interest, professional opportunity, or chance of winning.ACTIVE
116
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2503UNLAWFUL ACTS AND PRACTICES. Unfair methods of competition, unconscionable acts or practices, and unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce are hereby declared unlawful.ACTIVE
117
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2504RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. The department may adopt rules which set forth with specificity acts or practices that violate this part and which prescribe procedural rules for the administration of this part.ACTIVE
118
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2505INVESTIGATIVE POWERS OF ENFORCING AUTHORITY. If, by his or her own inquiry or as a result of complaints, the enforcing authority has reason to believe that a person has engaged in, or is engaging in, an act or practice that violates this part, he or she may administer oaths and affirmations, subpoena witnesses or matter, and collect evidence. Within 3 days after the service of a subpoena or at any time before the return date specified therein, whichever is longer, the party served may file in the district court and serve upon the enforcing authority a petition for an order modifying or setting aside the subpoena. The petitioner may raise any objection or privilege which would be available under this subchapter or upon service of such subpoena in a civil action. The subpoena shall inform the party served of his or her rights under this subsection.ACTIVE
119
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2505(a)(a) Upon failure of a person without lawful excuse to obey a subpoena and upon reasonable notice to all persons affected, the enforcing authority may apply to the district court for an order compelling compliance.ACTIVE
120
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2505(b)(b) The enforcing authority may request that an individual who refuses to comply with a subpoena on the ground that testimony or matter may incriminate him or her be ordered by the court to provide the testimony or matter. Except in a prosecution for perjury, an individual who complies with a court order to provide testimony or matter after asserting a privilege against self-incrimination to which he or she is entitled by law shall not have the testimony or matter so provided, or evidence derived therefrom, received against him or her in any criminal investigation or proceeding.ACTIVE
121
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2505(c)(c) Any person upon whom a subpoena is served pursuant to this section shall comply with the terms thereof unless otherwise provided by order of the court. Any person who fails to appear with the intent to avoid, evade, or prevent compliance in whole or in part with any investigation under this part or who removes from any place, conceals, withholds, mutilates, alters, or destroys, or by any other means falsifies any documentary material in the possession, custody, or control of any person subject to any such subpoena, or knowingly conceals any relevant information with the intent to avoid, evade, or prevent compliance shall be liable for a civil penalty of not more than $5,000, reasonable attorney’s fees, and costs.ACTIVE
122
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2506REMEDIES OF ENFORCING AUTHORITY. The enforcing authority may bring:ACTIVE
123
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2506(a)(a) An action to obtain a declaratory judgment that an act or practice violates this part.ACTIVE
124
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2506(b)(b) An action to enjoin any person who has violated, is violating, or is otherwise likely to violate, this part.ACTIVE
125
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2506(c)(c) An action on behalf of one or more consumers or governmental entities for the actual damages caused by an act or practice in violation of this part.ACTIVE
126
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2507The enforcing authority may terminate an investigation or an action upon acceptance of a person’s written assurance of voluntary compliance with this part. Acceptance of an assurance may be conditioned on a commitment to reimburse consumers or governmental entities, make contributions, pay civil penalties, pay attorney’s fees and costs, or take other appropriate corrective action. An assurance is not evidence of a prior violation of this part. However, unless an assurance has been rescinded by agreement of the parties or voided by a court for good cause, subsequent failure to comply with the terms of an assurance is prima facie evidence of a violation of this part. Such assurance is not a limitation upon any action or remedy available to a person aggrieved by a violation of this part.ACTIVE
127
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2508CIVIL PENALTY. Any person, firm, corporation, association, or entity, or any agent or employee of the foregoing, who is willfully using, or has willfully used, a method, act, or practice declared unlawful, or who is willfully violating any of the rules of the department adopted under this part, is liable for a civil penalty of not more than $10,000 for each such violation. Willful violations occur when the person knew or should have known that his or her conduct was unfair or deceptive or prohibited by rule. This civil penalty may be recovered in any action brought under this part by the enforcing authority; or the enforcing authority may terminate any investigation or action upon agreement by the person, firm, corporation, association, or entity, or the agent or employee of the foregoing, to pay a stipulated civil penalty. The department or the court may waive any such civil penalty if the person, firm, corporation, association, or entity, or the agent or employee of the foregoing, has previously made full restitution or reimbursement or has paid actual damages to the consumers or governmental entities who have been injured by the unlawful act or practice or rule violation. If civil penalties are assessed in any litigation, the enforcing authority is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.ACTIVE
128
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2509CEASE AND DESIST ORDER; PROCEDURES. Whenever the Department of Justice has reason to believe that a person has been, or is, violating this part, and if it appears to the department that a cease and desist order against such violation would be in the interest of the public, it shall issue and serve upon such person a complaint and order stating its charges in that respect and containing a notice of a hearing upon a day and at the place therein fixed at least 5 days after the service of said complaint. No cease and desist order shall act as a limitation upon any other action or remedy available to a person aggrieved by a violation of this act.ACTIVE
129
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2510Any person who violates a cease and desist order of the department after it has become final and while such order is in effect shall forfeit and pay to the state a civil penalty of not more than $5,000 for each violation which shall accrue to the state and may be recovered in a civil action brought by the state. Each separate violation of such an order shall be a separate offense, except that in the case of a violation through continuing failure or neglect to obey a final order of the department, each day of continuance of such failure or neglect shall be deemed a separate offense.ACTIVE
130
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2511The department may modify or set aside its order at any time by rehearing upon its own motion when such rehearing is in the interest of the public welfare.ACTIVE
131
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2512OTHER INDIVIDUAL REMEDIES. Without regard to any other remedy or relief to which a person is entitled, anyone aggrieved by a violation of this part may bring an action to obtain a declaratory judgment that an act or practice violates this part and to enjoin a person who has violated, is violating, or is otherwise likely to violate this part.ACTIVE
132
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2512(a)(a) In any action brought by a person who has suffered a loss as a result of a violation of this part, such person may recover actual damages, plus attorney’s fees and court costs.ACTIVE
133
4 M.S.C. 1 § 2512(b)(b) The remedies of this act are in addition to remedies otherwise available for the same conduct under state or local law.ACTIVE
134

CHAPTER I. RACKETEER INFLUENCED CORRUPT ORGANIZATIONS ACT
140
141
142
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS
143
144
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1101The term “Racketeering Activity” shall refer to:ACTIVE
145
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1101(a)(a) Any act or threat involving murder, kidnapping, battery, use of deadly weapons in the commission of an offense, gambling, arson, robbery, bribery, extortion, dealing in obscene matter, bribery, embezzlement, fraud, obstruction of justice, obstruction of criminal investigations, tampering with a witness, victim, or informant; monetary transactions of unlawfully gained property, murder for hire, or weapons trafficking.ACTIVE
146
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1102The term "enterprise” shall include:ACTIVE
147
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1102(a)(a) For the purposes of this Chapter, "enterprise" means any person, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity; or any association, or group of persons associated in fact although not a legal entity; and it includes illicit as well as licit enterprises and governmental as well as other entities.ACTIVE
148
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1103The term “person” shall include:ACTIVE
149
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1103(a)(a) Any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property.ACTIVE
150
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1104The term "pattering of racketeering activity" shall refer to:ACTIVE
151
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1104(a)(a) At least two acts of racketeering activity, one of which occurred after the effective date of this chapter and the last of which occurred within six months (excluding any period of imprisonment) after the commission of a prior act of racketeering activity.ACTIVE
152
153
SUBCHAPTER II. RACKETEERING
154
155
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1201It shall be unlawful for any person through a pattern of racketeering activity or through collection of an unlawful debt to acquire or maintain, directly or indirectly, any interest in or control of any enterprise which is engaged in, or the activities of which affect commerce.ACTIVE
156
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1202It shall be unlawful for any person employed by or associated with any enterprise engaged in, or the activities of which affect commerce, to conduct or participate, directly or indirectly, in the conduct of such enterprise’s affairs through a pattern of racketeering activity or collection of unlawful debt.ACTIVE
157
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1203It shall be unlawful for any person to conspire to violate any of the provisions of this subsection.ACTIVE
158
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1203(a)(a) Whoever violates any provision of this subsection is guilty of racketeering which shall be a felony punishable by up to 35 minutes in jail.ACTIVE
159
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1204In proceedings of racketeering, the Attorney General may petition the court to dissolve a business, and force the immediate sale of their properties, and divide outstanding debts amongst its liable persons.ACTIVE
160
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1205The Attorney General or other authorized attorney for the government may petition the State District Court in the relevant judicial district for the seizure of any assets, securities, assets, or money derived from or used in racketeering activity. ACTIVE
161
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1206The Attorney General may sue on behalf of the State any organization engaged in a pattern of racketeering activity, or any individual engaged in a pattern of racketeering activity, to recoup treble damages of any offenses committed against the State or any of it's officers.ACTIVE
162
4 M.S.C. 2 § 1207Whoever is convicted of 1 M.S.C. § 5202 “Racketeering” or 1 M.S.C. § 5203 “Racketeering conspiracy” shall forfeit to the State of Mayflower any (1) interest in; (2) security of; (3) claim against, or; (4) property or contractual right of any kind affording a source of influence over any enterprise which the person has established, operated, controlled, conducted, or participated in the conduct of, in violation of § 5202 or § 5203, and any property constituting, or derived from, any proceeds which the person obtained, directly or indirectly, from racketeering activity.ACTIVE
163
164
CHAPTER II. GANGS AND DANGEROUS CRIMINAL ORGANIZATIONS
165
166
167
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS
168
169
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2101The term “Criminal Street Gang” shall refer to:ACTIVE
170
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2101(a)(a) Any ongoing organization, association, or group of three or more persons, whether formal or informal, having as one of its primary activities the commission of one or more criminal acts or racketeering activity, whose members individually or collectively engage in or have engaged in a pattern of criminal or racketeering activity; or,ACTIVE
171
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2101(b)(b) Any organization association, or group of three or more persons, whether formal or informal, declared by the Governor, Attorney General, or the Mayflower Bureau of Investigation Director by public proclamation, as a criminal street gang; orACTIVE
172
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2101(c)(c) Any organization, association, or group of two or more persons participating in criminal or racketeering activity in conjunction with a criminal street gang.ACTIVE
173
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2102The term “person” or "player" shall be used interchangably and shall refer to:ACTIVE
174
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2102(a)(a) any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property; ACTIVE
175
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2103The term "Joint Terrorism Task Force Commander" shall refer to:REPEALED
176
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2103(a)(a) The Commander of the Joint Terrorism Task Force under the Attorney General.REPEALED
177
178
SUBCHAPTER II. STREET GANGS
179
180
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2201A person shall be guilty of coercing, inducing, or soliciting membership in a criminal street gang if the person knowingly causes, enables, encourages, recruits, or solicits another person to become a member of a criminal street gang which, as a condition of initiation, admission, membership, or continued membership, requires the commission of any conduct which constitutes an offense punishable as a felony or misdemeanor. This charge shall be a felony punishable by up to 45 minutes of incarceration. ACTIVE
181
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2202A person shall be guilty of engaging in organized criminal activity if, with the intent to establish, maintain, or participate in a combination or in the profits of a combination or as a member of a criminal street gang, the person commits or conspires to commit one or more of the following: murder, arson, aggravated robbery, robbery, burglary, theft, aggravated kidnapping, kidnapping, aggravated assault, forgery, deadly conduct, assault, burglary of a motor vehicle, unauthorized use of a motor vehicle, or any racketeering activity, or any felony. This charge shall be a felony punishable by up to 50 minutes of incarceration.ACTIVE
182
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2203A person shall be guilty of directing the activities of a criminal street gang if the person, as part of the identifiable leadership of a of a criminal street gang, knowingly finances, directs, or supervises the commission of, or a conspiracy to commit one or more of the following: murder, arson, aggravated robbery, robbery, burglary, theft, aggravated kidnapping, kidnapping, aggravated assault, forgery, deadly conduct, assault, burglary of a motor vehicle, unauthorized use of a motor vehicle, or any racketeering activity, or any felony. This charge shall be a felony punishable by up to 50 minutes of incarceration.ACTIVE
183
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2204Any law enforcement officer with an active burn permit shall be further authorized to execute a controlled burn on vehicle used by a criminal street gang in conjunction with criminal activity, or purchased as a result of proceeds derived from the unlawful activities of a criminal street gang. Furthermore, any Guardsman may conduct a controlled burn on any vehicle used by a criminal street gang to effectuate an attack on any Military Exclusion Zone.J. INACTIVE
184
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2204(a)(a) This provision shall only take effect if authorized by the Governor, Attorney General, or the Mayflower Bureau of Investigation Director for a specific timeframe or organization.J. INACTIVE
185
4 M.S.C. 2 § 2205The Mayflower Bureau of Investigation Director or their designee shall have the responsibility to maintain a public listing of all recognised criminal street gangs, as defined under 4 M.S.C. 2 § 2101 and its subsections, for which there will be a review every 30 days of their designated status to determine if they are an active and current threat to state security and safety.ACTIVE
186

CHAPTER I. STATE SECURITY ACT
192
193
194
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS
195
196
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1101The term “classified information” shall refer to:ACTIVE
197
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1101(a)(a) Information regulated by the provisions of this act to be confidential; specifically designated by a State Government Agency for limited or restricted dissemination or distributionACTIVE
198
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1102The term “department head” shall refer to:ACTIVE
199
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1102(a)(a) The first-in-command of an agency under the executive cabinet, or the head of a law enforcement agency within the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
200
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1103The term “security clearance” shall refer to:ACTIVE
201
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1103(a)(a) An official authorization to access classified information designated by the provisions of this act.ACTIVE
202
203
SUBCHAPTER II. CLASSIFICATION LEVELS
204
205
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1201Information may be classified at one of the following four levels upon meeting its’ criteria:ACTIVE
206
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1201(a)(a) “Top Secret” shall be applied to information, the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expected to cause exceptionally grave damage to the state security or impede ongoing criminal investigations or judicial processes that the original classification authority is able to identify or describe.ACTIVE
207
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1201(b)(b) “Secret” shall be applied to information, the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expected to cause serious damage to the state security or impede ongoing criminal investigations or judicial processes.ACTIVE
208
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1201(c)(c) “Confidential” shall be applied to information, the unauthorized disclosure of which reasonably could be expected to cause damage to the state security or impede ongoing criminal investigations or judicial processes.ACTIVE
209
210
SUBCHAPTER III. CLASSIFICATION STANDARDS
211
212
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1301At the time of original classification, the following shall appear on the face of each classified document, or shall be applied to other classified media in an appropriate manner in order to be considered classified information:ACTIVE
213
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1301(a)(a) One of the three classification levels defined in Subchapter II of this Chapter.ACTIVE
214
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1301(b)(b) The date of classificationACTIVE
215
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1301(c)(c) The username of the individual with classification authority.ACTIVE
216
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1301(d)(d) The date that is no more than 1 year from the date of original classification pursuant to paragraph (a)(ii) of this section.ACTIVE
217
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1302Classified material shall remain protected under its classification for no more than one (1) year.ACTIVE
218
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1302(a)(a) An original classification authority may extend the duration of classification, change the level of classification, or reclassify specific information only when the standards and procedures for classifying information under this act, and by authority of the Governor to classify information.ACTIVE
219
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1303The Governor shall have the authority to issue orders on the handling, procedure, criteria, or any otherwise necessary provisions for classifying information.ACTIVE
220
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1304Categories for the classification of information must serve a reasonable and objective purpose of securing information that if disclosed, would be either damaging to state security, public safety, criminal investigations, defense, or life-threatening harm to individuals.ACTIVE
221
222
SUBCHAPTER IV. CLASSIFICATION AUTHORITY
223
224
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1401The authority to classify information originally shall only be exercised by:ACTIVE
225
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1401(a)(a) The Governor of the State of Mayflower, in the performance of executive duties, the Lieutenant Governor;ACTIVE
226
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1401(b)(b) Department heads and officials designed by the Governor through executive decree.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 3 § 1401(c)(c) State government officials delegated this authority by paragraph (b) of this section.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 3 § 1401(d)(d) The Adjutant General of the Mayflower National Guard and his deputy.ACTIVE
229
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1402“Confidential,” “Secret” or “Top Secret” may be delegated by the Governor; in the performance of executive duties, the Lieutenant Governor; or a department head or official designated pursuant to paragraph 1401 of this section; or a subordinate designated by a department head to classify information.ACTIVE
230
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1402(a)(a) “Top Secret” or “Secret” original classification authority may be delegated only by the Governor; in the performance of executive duties, the Lieutenant Governor; or a department head or official designated pursuant to paragraph (a)(ii) of this section.REPEALED
231
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1402(b)(b) “Confidential” original classification authority may be delegated only by the Governor; in the performance of executive duties, the Lieutenant Governor; or a department head or official designated pursuant to paragraph 1401 of this section; or a subordinate designated by a department head to classify information.REPEALED

SUBCHAPTER V. CLEARANCES
235
236
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1501The Department of Justice through the Attorney General shall have the authority to issue, revoke, and regulate security clearances within the State of Mayflower. The Attorney General may designate officials who hold the authority to issue, revoke, and regulate security clearances.ACTIVE
237
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1501(a)(a) This power shall not extend to Commissioned Officers of the Mayflower National Guard, although the Attorney General shall retain the power to petition in writing, to the Governor, for the suspension, revocation or regulation of security clearances for members of Commissioned Officers of the Mayflower National Guard.ACTIVE
238
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1502No individual may view classified information without a security clearance of the same classification level.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER VI. ENFORCEMENT
242
243
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1601Whoever knowingly and willfully communicates, furnishes, transmits, or otherwise makes available to an unauthorized person, or publishes, or uses in any manner prejudicial to the safety or interest of the State or for the benefit of any foreign government to the detriment of the State of Mayflower any classified information shall be guilty of “Unauthorized distribution of classified information” as defined in 1 M.S.C. 1 § 1101, which shall be considered a capital felony.ACTIVE
244
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1602Any person who distributes, or attempt to distribute, information classified by an authorized entity of the State of Mayflower to agents or subjects of foreign governments, with intent or reason to believe that it is to be used to the injury of the State of Mayflower or to the advantage of a foreign government shall be guilty of “Espionage” as defined in 1 M.S.C. 1 § 1102, which shall be considered a capital felony.ACTIVE
245
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1603Any person that violates paragraph (b) of this section in time of war shall be punished by death or imprisonment for no more than three (3) hours.ACTIVE
246
4 M.S.C. 3 § 1604Any person that violates paragraph (b) of this section shall be punished by death or imprisonment for no more than sixty (60) minutes.ACTIVE

CHAPTER II. THE LUCAS ACT - SUNSHINE PROVISIONS
249
250
251
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS
252
253
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2101The term "Lucas" shall refer to:ACTIVE
254
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2101(a)(a) columbianethos, the Inaugural Attorney General and a Founding Father of the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
255
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2102The term “legistlative body” shall refer to:ACTIVE
256
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2102(a)(a) The governing body of a municipality or county.ACTIVE
257
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2102(b)(b) A commission, committee, board, or other body of a municipality or county, whether permanent or temporary, decisionmaking or advisory, created by charter, ordinance, resolution, or formal action of a legislative body. However, advisory committees, composed solely of the members of the legislative body that are less than a quorum of the legislative body are not legislative bodies, except that standing committees of a legislative body, irrespective of their composition, which have a continuing subject matter jurisdiction, or a meeting schedule fixed by charter, ordinance, resolution, or formal action of a legislative body are legislative bodies for purposes of this chapter.ACTIVE
258
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2103The term “meeting” shall refer to:ACTIVE
259
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2103(a)(a) Any congregation of a majority of the members of a legislative body at the same time and location, including teleconference location, to hear, discuss, deliberate, or take action on any item that is within the subject matter jurisdiction of the legislative body.ACTIVE
260
261
SUBCHAPTER II. SUNSHINE PROVISIONS
262
263
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2201All meetings of the legislative body of a municipality or county shall be open and public, and all persons shall be permitted to attend any meeting of the legislative body of a local agency, except as otherwise provided in this chapter.ACTIVE
264
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2202No legislative body shall take action by secret ballot, whether preliminary or final.ACTIVE
265
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2202(a)(a) The legislative body of a municipality or county shall publicly report any action taken and the vote or abstention on that action of each member present for the action.ACTIVE
266
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2203No legislative body shall require public comments to be submitted in advance of a meeting and must provide an opportunity for the public to address the legislative body and offer comment in real time.ACTIVE
267
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2204A legislative body of a municipality of county must publish the date, time, and location of all meetings in a place viewable and accessible to the general public no later then one hour before the time of any meeting.ACTIVE
268
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2204(a)(a) The Clerk or Presiding Officer of such legislative body must advise the public of any changes to the date, time, and location of published meetings as described in this subchapter.ACTIVE
269
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2205No legislative body of a local agency shall prohibit or otherwise restrict the broadcast of its open and public meetings in the absence of a reasonable finding that the broadcast cannot be accomplished without noise, or obstruction of view that would constitute a persistent disruption of the proceedings.ACTIVE
270
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2206A legislative body must maintain and publish for public access all agendas, proposed resolutions, bills, or acts of the body, a record of attendance, the minutes of any held meeting, and the voting record of any member of the legislative body.ACTIVE
271
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2207The Clerk or Presiding Officer must furnish to any person who so requests a record of any business before the legislative body for which they clerk or preside over.ACTIVE
272
4 M.S.C. 3 § 2208A legislative body may hold an emergency session in the event of an emergency, which shall be defined as a crippling disaster, mass destruction, terrorist act, or threatened terrorist activity that poses peril so immediate and significant that requiring a legislative body to provide one-hour notice before holding an emergency meeting under this section may endanger the public health, safety, or both, as determined by a majority of the members of the legislative body. In such circumstance, the one-hour requirement is waived.ACTIVE
273

CHAPTER III. THE LUCAS ACT - PREVENTION OF PERNICIOUS POLITICAL ACTIVITIES PROVISIONS
275
276
277
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS

279
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3101The term "employee" shall refer to:ACTIVE
280
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3101(a)(a) Any individual employed by, or contracted to work in, any agency, department, office, division, or body of the State of Mayflower or political subdivisions thereof within the Executive Branch, including all law enforcement officers of the State.ACTIVE
281
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3102The term “restricted state employee” shall refer to:ACTIVE
282
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3102(a)(a) Any individual—ACTIVE
283
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3102(a)(i)(i) employed as a prosecutor within the Department of Justice;ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER II. PROVISIONS
291
292
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201No state employee shall:ACTIVE
293
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(a)(a) Engage in political activity while on-duty, or while clearly identifiable as a member as an employee of the State or any political subdivisions thereof, or within any property of the State or any political subdivisions thereof. ACTIVE
294
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(b)(b) Invite subordinate employees to political events, or otherwise encourage or suggest that they engage in political activity of any form.ACTIVE
295
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(c)(c) Solicit or discourage the political activity of any person with business before the agency, department, division, office, or body of the State or any political subdivison thereof that they are employed within.ACTIVE
296
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(c)(i)(i) This includes any individiual a law enforcement officer makes contact with whilst on-duty.ACTIVE
297
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(d)(d) Solicit, accept, or recieve political donations or contributions.ACTIVE
298
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3201(e)(e) Use official authority to interfere with an election, or use official authority in any way while engaged in political activity.ACTIVE
299
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202No restricted state employee shall:ACTIVE
300
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(a)(a) Take part in partisan political management.ACTIVE
301
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(b)(b) Assist in or take part in coordinating partisan voter registration drives.ACTIVE
302
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(c)(c) Campaign for or against candidates in an election.ACTIVE
303
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(d)(d) Circulate nominating petitions.ACTIVE
304
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(e)(e) Distribute campaign literature by any medium.ACTIVE
305
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(f)(f) Make campaign speeches for or against candidates in partisan elections.ACTIVE
306
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202(g)(g) Participate in partisan political campaigns. ACTIVE
307
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3203Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to prohibit a state employee or restricted state employee from attending political rallies, meetings, or fundraisers, or from being a non-partisan candidate in an election, or expressing opinions about partisan groups and candidates in partisan elections while not at work or using official authority, or express opinions about political issues, or joining partisan political groups, or sign nominating petitions, or vote as they choose.ACTIVE
308
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3203Restricted state employees shall be exempt from the restrictions listed in 4 M.S.C. 3 § 3202 if the following conditions are met:ACTIVE
309
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3204(a)(a) A leave of absence is filed for the duration of the election period where the restricted state employee will be able to be present in-game and online and not required to complete their duties in their respective roles; andACTIVE
310
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3204(b)(b) the restricted employee does not conduct any official duties associated with their role during this period.”ACTIVE
311
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3205Restricted state employees shall be immune from administrative action during election periods if they follow the conditions set out in 4 M.S.C. 3 § 3204, unless they commit any of the following:ACTIVE
312
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3205(a)(a) Conduct official duties relating to their role in violation of their leave of absence; orACTIVE
313
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3205(b)(b) if the restricted state employee commits any criminal violations during their leave that would warrant action against them.”ACTIVE
314
315
SUBCHAPTER III. ENFORCEMENT
316
317
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3301The Attorney General or his designee shall receive any allegation of a violation of this Chapter and shall investigate the allegation to the extent necessary to determine whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this Chapter has occurred.ACTIVE
318
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3302The Attorney General or his designee shall fully investigate any alleged violations. ACTIVE
319
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3303The Attorney General or his designee, upon conclusion of the investigation, shall either determine no violation was made, or submit a notice to the violator of the violations under this Chapter they sustained. Such notice will include a full description of the violation, and the corrective action taken, which may include:ACTIVE
320
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3303(a)(a) referral to the internal investigative unit of the agency which the violator is a member of;ACTIVE
321
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3303(b)(b) a fine of no more then $10,000; orACTIVE
322
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3303(c)(c) removal from state service or a reduction in grade or rank;ACTIVE
323
4 M.S.C. 3 § 3303(c)(i)(i) removal or reduction may only take place after the filing of an administrative action on behalf of the State against the violator.ACTIVE

CHAPTER IV. PARTY POWERS ACT
326
327
328
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS
329
330
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4101“Political Party” shall refer to any political organization registered with the Mayflower Elections Commission as a political party.
ACTIVE
331
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4102“Espionage” shall refer to the act of using informants or illicit and clandestine methods in order to obtain secret information from an organization, information which is not made readily accessible to the public and is not intended for public awareness.
ACTIVE
332
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4103“Secret Police” shall refer to an organization that carries out illicit and clandestine methods of intelligence gathering regarding communication between their targets.
ACTIVE
333
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4104“Paramilitary” shall refer to an organization, not associated with the Federal or State government, that carries out military activities through the employment of armed personnel and utilization of firearms, explosives and other weaponry.
ACTIVE
334
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4105“Security Contractor” shall refer to a business registered with the Department of State as a security company and have a license to offer security contracting services to the public.
ACTIVE
335
336
SUBCHAPTER II. PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES
337
338
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4201Political parties shall be prohibited from carrying out espionage on other political parties.
ACTIVE
339
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4202Political parties shall be prohibited from having a paramilitary or other non-government militia as a direct subdivision of their party organization.
ACTIVE
340
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4203Political parties shall be prohibited from having a secret police or clandestine intelligence bureau as a direct subdivision of their party organization.
ACTIVE
341
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4204Political parties shall be allowed to contract a security contractor business for protection of events, buildings and any other needs.ACTIVE
342
343
SUBCHAPTER III. ENFORCEMENT
344
345
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4301Any political party that knowingly takes part in any prohibited activities outlined in this act, shall be unregistered as a political party by the Mayflower Elections Commission.
ACTIVE
346
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4302The registered leader of a political party found to have taken part in prohibited activities shall be suspended from establishing any political party for 3 (three) months.
ACTIVE
347
4 M.S.C. 3 § 4303Should a party be found to have taken part in prohibited activities and be shut down by the Mayflower Elections Commission, no individual shall be allowed to establish a political party under the previous party name for 3 (three) months.
ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER II. DEFINITIONS
462
463
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1200The term “political subdivision" shall refer to:ACTIVE
464
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1200(a)(a) Regional jurisdictions generally include but are not limited to the State, County or Municipal governments residing within the boundaries of the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
465
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1201The term “county law enforcement” shall refer to:ACTIVE
466
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1201(a)(a) Any government agency within the jurisdiction of a county political subdivision within the State of Mayflower that enforces the law.ACTIVE
467
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1202The term “municipal law enforcement” shall refer to:ACTIVE
468
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1202(a)(a) Any government agency within the jurisdiction of a municipal political subdivision that enforces the law.ACTIVE
469
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1203The term “budget” shall refer to:ACTIVE
470
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1203(a)(a) The limitations on employment and membership within a government agency as afforded by law.ACTIVE
471
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1203(b)(b) The provisions of other relevant expenditures of a government agency as afforded by law.ACTIVE
472
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1204The term “port authority” shall refer to:ACTIVE
473
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1204(a)(a) A governmental or quasi-governmental entity established by statute or through intergovernmental agreement, responsible for the administration, regulation, and security of one or more seaports, harbors, or rail terminals not operated by a business entity subject to the Class I Railway Act. ACTIVE
474
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1204(b)(b) The Port Authority of Mayflower and QuanahassitACTIVE
475
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1205The term “department” or “agency” shall refer to:ACTIVE
476
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1205(a)(a) Any public department, law enforcement agency, or office within the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
477
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1205(b)(b) A governmental or quasi-governmental entity established by statute or through intergovernmental agreement.ACTIVE
478
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1206The term “M.S.C.”, “MSC”, or “M.S.C” shall refer to:ACTIVE
479
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1206(a)(a) The Mayflower Code of Statutes.ACTIVE
480
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1207The term “detain” shall refer to:ACTIVE
481
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1207(a)(a) A situation in which a peace officer, possessing reasonable suspicion that a crime has been committed, legally orders an individual under investigation to remain within the peace officer's immediate presence and not to leave. ACTIVE
482
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1208The term “arrest” shall refer to:ACTIVE
483
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1208(a)(a) The act in which a peace officer, having probable cause to believe that a crime has been committed, takes a suspect into custody.ACTIVE
484
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1209The term “book” shall refer to:ACTIVE
485
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1209(a)(a) The act in which a peace officer sends a person to a local, county or state jail using a booking terminal.ACTIVE
486
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1210The term “second” shall refer to:ACTIVE
487
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1210(a)(a) The duration of approximately 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the Cesium-133 atom.ACTIVE
488
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1211The term “warrant” shall refer to:ACTIVE
489
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1211(a)(a) A written order issued by a judge, authorized by law, directing a law enforcement officer to perform a specific act, such as the arrest of a person, the search and seizure of property, or the execution of a judicial orderACTIVE
490
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1212The term “police officer” or “peace officer” shall refer to:ACTIVE
491
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1212(a)(a) Any person who is a sworn member of a law enforcement agency and is authorized by the State to enforce laws, maintain public order, prevent and investigate crimes, and protect life and property. This definition includes any federal peace officer, and any fire marshal of a political subdivision.ACTIVE
492
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1213The term “department head” shall refer to:ACTIVE
493
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1213(a)(a) The first-in-command of an agency under the executive cabinet, or the head of a law enforcement agency within the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
494
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1214The term “force” shall refer to:ACTIVE
495
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1214(a)(a) Any physical effort used by a peace officer to compel compliance by an unwilling subject. This includes, but is not limited to, physical restraint, physical strikes, use of chemical agents, use of electronic control devices, and use of firearms.ACTIVE
496
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1215The term “law enforcement training institute” shall refer to:ACTIVE
497
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1215(a)(a) The Mayflower Law Enforcement Training Institute.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 1215(b)(b) Any state-operated entity established to provide training and certification for individuals preparing to fulfill the duties of a peace officer.ACTIVE
499
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1216The term “sheriff” shall refer to: ACTIVE
500
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1216(a)(a) The department head of a county law enforcement agency.ACTIVE
501
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1217The term “railroad police officer” has the same meaning as defined in 6 M.S.C. 2 § 1102(a).ACTIVE
502
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1218The term “police operation" shall refer to:ACTIVE
503
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1218(a)(a) A coordinated effort carried out by one or more peace officers with a clearly defined objective, which may include but is not limited to surveillance, investigation, apprehension, or enforcement actions.ACTIVE
504
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1219The term “firefighter" shall refer to:ACTIVE
505
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1219(a)(a) A fire chief and any other person employed in, or appointed to, a fire department and assigned to undertake fire protection services, and includes a volunteer firefighterACTIVE
506
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1220The term “fire protection services" shall refer to:ACTIVE
507
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1220(a)(a) A range of services including fire suppression, fire prevention, fire safety education, rescue operations, emergency medical services, and related health services. This also includes the training of individuals involved in any of these areas, and the provision of any single service or a combination thereof, as performed by qualified personnel such as firefighters, paramedics, or other emergency responders.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 1222The term “parking enforcement agent” or “parking enforcement officer” or “traffic warden” or “traffic infraction enforcement officer” shall refer to:ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 1222(a)(a) Any person who is not a peace officer that is employed with a municipal law enforcement agency or the Parks and Wildlife department and is authorized to enforce certain parking and traffic laws and aid peace officers in traffic operations.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER III. DUTIES AND CONDUCT OF A PEACE OFFICER
514
515
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301The duties of a peace officer shall include the following but is not limited to:ACTIVE
516
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(a)(a) preserving the peace;ACTIVE
517
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(b)(b) preventing crimes and other offenses;ACTIVE
518
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(c)(c) assisting victims of crime;ACTIVE
519
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(d)(d) apprehending criminals and other offenders who may lawfully be taken into custody;ACTIVE
520
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(e)(e) participating in prosecutions;ACTIVE
521
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(f)(f) executing warrants that are to be executed by peace officers and performing related duties;ACTIVE
522
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(g)(g) performing lawful duties as promulgated by their respective department head or the Attorney General;ACTIVE
523
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(h)(h) completing training required by this act, the peace officer’s respective department, or a law enforcement training institute; andACTIVE
524
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1301(i)(i) performing such other duties as assigned to the peace officer by this act or any other Act, including any prescribed duties.ACTIVE
525
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1302A peace officer shall not, in the course of their duties, treat any person in a manner that contravenes the Constitution of the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
526
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1303A peace officer shall not, by act or omission, do anything that the peace officer, at the time, knows or reasonably ought to know would infringe or deny a person’s rights or freedoms listed in the Constitution of the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
527
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1304A peace officer shall not make an arrest if, at the time of the arrest, the peace officer knows or reasonably ought to know that the arrest is unlawful.ACTIVE
528
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1305A peace officer shall not authorize or make a physical or psychological detention if, at the time of the detention, the peace officer knows or reasonably ought to know that the detention is unlawful.ACTIVE
529
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1306A peace officer shall not neglect the health or safety of any person who is in their custody as a result of the peace officer’s duties.ACTIVE
530
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1307A peace officer shall not use force unless:ACTIVE
531
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1307(a)(a) the force is used for the purpose of carrying out a lawful duty;ACTIVE
532
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1307(b)(b) the peace officer is entitled by statute or common law to use force for the purpose of carrying out that duty;ACTIVE
533
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1307(c)(c) the peace officer is acting on reasonable grounds; andACTIVE
534
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1307(d)(d) the force used is no more than is necessary given the circumstances.ACTIVE
535
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1308A peace officer shall not solicit, offer or take a bribe.ACTIVE
536
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1309A peace officer shall not use their position as a peace officer to do any of the following:ACTIVE
537
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1309(a)(a) Use any information obtained through their position as a peace officer for personal advantage.ACTIVE
538
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1309(b)(b) Willingly and knowingly interfere with the administration of justice.ACTIVE
539
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1309(c)(c) Use departmental property or resources for personal or financial benefit.ACTIVE
540
541
SUBCHAPTER IV. JURISDICTION OF A PEACE OFFICER
542
543
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1401A peace officer has the authority to act as such throughout the state but is bound by provisions of the state code that stipulate restrictions.ACTIVE
544
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1401(a)(a) No county charter or municipal charter shall limit the authority of a peace officer to act as such throughout the State.ACTIVE
545
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1402If a law enforcement agency is specifically established to serve a particular subdivision, the respective department head is responsible for ensuring that their law enforcement agency’s policies maintain peace officers in areas in or around that political subdivision.ACTIVE
546
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1402(a)(a) This code does not apply to postal inspectors.ACTIVE
547
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1403If a law enforcement agency is specifically established as a governmental or quasi-governmental entity established by statute or through intergovernmental agreement, the respective department head is responsible for ensuring that their law enforcement agency’s policies maintain peace officers in areas or around the property managed by the entity, with a focus to the protection of properties that the entity owns, possesses or administers and the persons upon those properties.ACTIVE
548
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1403(a)(a) This code does not apply to postal inspectors.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER VI - ELIGIBILITY TO GAIN AND MAINTAIN PEACE OFFICER STATUS
561
562
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601No person shall be hired, carry out the duties, or act in the capacity of a peace officer unless he or she:ACTIVE
563
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(a)(a) is a resident of the State;ACTIVE
564
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(b)(b) is physically and mentally able to perform the duties of the position;ACTIVE
565
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(c)(c) does not have any pending criminal matter before any court of the State or the Union of Columbia in which the person is named as the defendant and has been reasonably notified of such matter;ACTIVE
566
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(d)(d) has not been convicted of any degree of misconduct within the last fifty (50) days;ACTIVE
567
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(e)(e) holds an active certification by a recognized law enforcement training institute; andACTIVE
568
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1601(f)(f) is actively employed by a recognized law enforcement entity within the State for the purposes of keeping the peace.ACTIVE
569
4 M.S.C. 5 § 1602If a person is convicted of any degree of misconduct, the sentencing judge may grant an exemption from compliance with 4 M.S.C. § 1601(d), either in full or for a period of up to fifty (50) days.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER II. PEACE OFFICER PRIVILEGE TO CARRY PISTOLS OFF DUTY
635
636
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2201For the purposes of this subchapter, the term “pistol” shall be defined as:ACTIVE
637
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2201(a)(a) a weapon originally designed, made, and intended to fire a projectile (bullet) from one or more barrels when held in one hand, and having: ACTIVE
638
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2201(a)(i)(i) a chamber(s) as an integral part(s) of, or permanently aligned with, the bore(s); andACTIVE
639
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2201(a)(ii)(ii) a short stock designed to be gripped by one hand at an angle to and extending below the line of the bore(s).ACTIVE
640
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2201(b)(b) This definition includes any ammunition compatible and intended for use with the pistol.ACTIVE
641
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2202A department head of a law enforcement agency must include a provision in their respective department’s policies regarding the privilege to use a pistol issued by the department when not acting in the capacity of the respective law enforcement agency.ACTIVE
642
4 M.S.C. 5 § 22031 M.S.C. § 1403 “Unlicensed possession of non-civilian equipment” shall not extend to peace officers who are permitted under their respective department’s policies to use a pistol issued by the department when not acting in the capacity of their respective law enforcement agency.ACTIVE
643
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2203(a)(a) This subchapter only applies when the pistol is physically present on the person, and does not extend to:ACTIVE
644
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2203(a)(i)(i) a vehicle;ACTIVE
645
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2203(a)(ii)(ii) a dwelling; orACTIVE
646
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2203(a)(iii)(iii) any other method of storage where the pistol would not be present on the person.ACTIVE
647
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2203(b)(b) This subchapter does not exempt any person from any requirements or responsibilities normally required when carrying a firearm.ACTIVE
648
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2204Any peace officer who carries a pistol off duty under this subchapter is required to identify themselves to any peace officer upon request, in addition to stating any departments they are employed by.ACTIVE
649

SUBCHAPTER III. EMERGENCY VEHICLE EXEMPTIONS AND PEDESTRIAN RIGHTS
651
652
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2301The authorized driver of a vehicle with an active emergency light recognized under 6 M.S.C. 4 § 3102 is exempt from Title 2 of the M.S.C., provided that the authorized driver operates the vehicle with due care in the lawful performance of their duties.ACTIVE
653
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2302Notwithstanding 4 M.S.C. 5 § 2301, a peace officer who is operating a vehicle that is equipped with an emergency light recognized under 6 M.S.C. 4 § 3102 is exempt from Title 2 of the M.S.C., provided that the peace officer operates said vehicle with due care in the lawful performance of their duties.ACTIVE
654
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2302(a)(a) This code applies regardless if the emergency light is active or not.ACTIVE
655
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2302(b)(b) Any recipient authorized under 6 M.S.C. 4 § 3302 enjoys the same exemption from Title 2 of the M.S.C., provided that the recipent operates their motor vehicle with due care in the performance of their duties.ACTIVE
656
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2303An authorized driver operating a vehicle in accordance with 4 M.S.C. 5 §§ 2301-2302 shall not be held civilly liable in the event a pedestrian is struck, provided that the driver was acting with due regard, unless negligence or misconduct is demonstrated.ACTIVE
657
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2303(a)(a) This immunity extends to the employer of the authorized driver, unless negligence or misconduct is demonstrated.ACTIVE
658
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2304Presumption of non-liability shall apply where evidence indicates the pedestrian intentionally or neglectfully entered or remained in the path of a vehicle where the authorized driver is operating with due regard and care.ACTIVE
659
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2304(a)(a) Where the authorized vehicle is operating in response to an emergency and has active emergency lighting systems as required by 6 M.S.C. § 3102, a presumption of negligence or a wilful act unless evidence clearly contradicts that presumption.ACTIVE
660
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2305Pedestrians must yield the right-of-way to emergency vehicles as described in 4 M.S.C. 5 §§ 2301-2302.ACTIVE
661
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2306Liability stipulated in 4 M.S.C. 5 §§ 2303-2304 shall not apply in cases where pedestrians are partaking in a lawful assembly or approved event.ACTIVE
662
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2307No monetary damages shall be awarded in a civil court under this Subchapter unless negligence or misconduct is demonstrated.ACTIVE
663
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2308Nothing in this Subchapter shall be construed to permit reckless operation of emergency vehicles or to diminish the standard of due regard required.ACTIVE
664
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2309“Due regard” for the purpose of this Subchapter shall hold the definition that an authorized driver acted within the constitutional rights of themselves and other road users and within the laws they are not exempted from promulgated by the Mayflower State Code.
ACTIVE
665
666
SUBCHAPTER IV. DUTY TO IDENTIFY
667
668
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2401When it is reasonably safe for a peace officer, every peace officer upon request from any person is required to:ACTIVE
669
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2401(a)(a) show their identification card;ACTIVE
670
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2401(b)(b) state the department they are acting in the capacity of; andACTIVE
671
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2401(c)(c) if applicable, state their callsign.ACTIVE
672
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402A peace officer is not required to identify themselves if:ACTIVE
673
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402(a)(a) it is not reasonably safe for the peace officer;ACTIVE
674
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402(b)(b) the peace officer is operating an emergency service vehicle;ACTIVE
675
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402(c)(c) the peace officer has already identified themselves to the same person within the last sixty (60) minutes;ACTIVE
676
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402(d)(d) the peace officer has declared themselves out of service; orACTIVE
677
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2402(e)(e) the peace officer is engaged in or participating in an authorized police operation where the act of providing identification would compromise the objective(s) of the operation.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER V. REGULATIONS
680
681
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2501The Attorney General may make regulations towards any law enforcement agency, personnel, or leadership, in the interest of ensuring that the law is enforced properly, ethical pratices are maintained, and the safety of the State is prioritized.ACTIVE
682
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2501(a)(a) Any public employee who violates a published law enforcement memorandum unintentionally as a result of negligence shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1304 "Misconduct."ACTIVE
683
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2501(b)(b) Any public employee who violates a published law enforcement memorandum knowingly or intentionally shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1303 "Gross Misconduct."ACTIVE
684
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2501(c)(c) All departments who employ law enforcement officers shall develop policies governing requirements for compliance with published memorandums, and punishment for disobedience from employees.ACTIVE
685
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2501(d)(d) The Attorney General may, at their discretion, may choose to outline certain instances in which there is individual liability of an officer rather than official liability in instances of failure to execute such memorandums. ACTIVE
686
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2502The Attorney General shall notify the head of any department effected of any creation, amendment, revocation, or any other alteration of a regulation prescribed under this subchapter.ACTIVE
687
4 M.S.C. 5 § 2503The provisions of any regulation prescribed by the Attorney General under this subchapter shall be interpreted as being in addition to, and not in derogation or restriction of, any power, jurisdiction or authority that may be exercised under this Chapter, the Constitution, or any other Chapter.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 2801In this Subtitle, any reference to a pronoun shall be interpreted to include all respective pronouns, regardless of gender. This inclusive interpretation applies to all provisions, ensuring gender neutrality and inclusivity throughout this act.ACTIVE

CHAPTER III. POLICE DETAINMENT LIMITATIONS
711
712
713
SUBCHAPTER I. SHORT TITLE AND DEFINITIONS
714
715
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3101This chapter may be cited as the "Police Detainment Act."ACTIVE
716
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3101(a)(a) This chapter shall dictate the powers and limitations of detainment by state certified peace officers, which shall extend to Conservation Officers established under Title 7 when acting in their official capacity.ACTIVE
717
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3101(a)(i)(i) This section shall not apply to members of the National Guard serving in their official capacity, except state certified peace officers acting as Military Police.ACTIVE
718
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3102The term "supervisor" shall refer to:ACTIVE
719
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3102(a)(a) Any employee tasked with supervisory roles by their respective department's policies, or as designated by the respective department head, or both.ACTIVE
720
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3103The term "traffic stop" shall refer to:ACTIVE
721
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3103(a)(a) A temporary detention of a motor vehicle and its operator by a peace officer on a highway to investigate any motor vehicle infraction, or any other violation of State law. A traffic stop starts when the peace officer and the motor vehicle being pulled over come to a full stop at any reasonable place.ACTIVE
722
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3104The term "interrogation" shall refer to:ACTIVE
723
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3104(a)(a) A temporary detention of a person by a peace officer where the person is informed of any relevant rights and is asked a series of questions by the peace officer. An interrogation starts when the peace officer finishes reading the detained person their relevant rights.ACTIVE
724
725
SUBCHAPTER II. GENERAL DETAINMENT LIMITS
726
727
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3201A traffic stop may not last more than twelve (12) minutes. ACTIVE
728
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3201(a)(a) After twelve (12) minutes have passed since the commencement of the traffic stop, all charges on the operator of the motor vehicle shall be void.ACTIVE
729
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202An interrogation may not last for more than forty-five (45) minutes.ACTIVE
730
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202(a)(a) After forty-five (45) minutes have passed since the start of the interrogation, or the peace officer conducting the interrogation has terminated the interrogation, the peace officer has an additional fifteen (15) minutes to charge the detained person with a crime.ACTIVE
731
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202(b)(b) If the peace officer conducting the interrogation takes longer than forty-five (45) minutes, no more questions may be asked and the interrogation shall conclude. The detained person shall be free to leave.ACTIVE
732
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202(b)(i)(i) This does not apply if the detained person willingly continues the interrogation. If the detained person willingly continues the interrogation, they shall be free to leave at any time unless the peace officer conducting the interrogation decides to charge the detained person with a crime, to which 4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202(a) shall take effect.ACTIVE
733
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202(c)(c) Proceeding the termination of the interrogation, if the peace officer that was conducting the interrogation takes longer than the additional fifteen (15) minutes allocated to book the detained person, the charges against the detained person shall be void.ACTIVE
734
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3203Any other detainment in any other setting shall not exceed more than twelve (12) minutes. For the purposes of this code, the detainment commences whenever the peace officer verbally informs the person that they are being detained, or places handcuffs on the person, or both.ACTIVE
735
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3203(a)(a) After twelve (12) minutes have passed since the commencement of the detainment, all charges against the detained person shall be void.ACTIVE
736
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3204If a detained person requests a bar certified attorney, any timer relevant to the detainment shall be halted. Upon the arrival of the detained person's bar certified attorney, or the detained person has informed the peace officer that their bar ceritifed attorney is no longer coming, the relevant detainment timer shall resume.ACTIVE
737
738
SUBCHAPTER III. INTERNAL DETAINMENT LIMITS
739
740
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3301Notwithstanding 4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202, an interrogation may last for up ninety (90) minutes provided the following conditions are met:ACTIVE
741
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3301(a)(a) the peace officer conducting the interrogation is employed by the same department as the detained person;ACTIVE
742
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3301(b)(b) the peace officer is a higher rank than the detained person in the department, or the peace officer is a member of that department's internal investigation unit formed under 4 M.S.C. 5 § 1701; andACTIVE
743
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3301(c)(c) the detained person has not been interrogated within the past twelve (12) hours under 4 M.S.C. 5 § 3202.ACTIVE
744
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3302(a) After ninety (90) minutes have passed since the start of the interrogation, or the peace officer conducting the interrogation has terminated the interrogation, the peace officer has an additional fifteen (15) minutes to charge the detained person with a crime. After the additional fifteen (15) minutes, all charges against the detained person shall be void.ACTIVE
745
746
SUBCHAPTER IV. SUPERVISOR REQUESTS; DETAINMENT PENDING WARRANT EXECUTION; TRANSPORTATION
747
748
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3401If any detained person requests a supervisor, any relevant detainment timer shall halt, provided that the peace officer detaining the detained person is not a supervisor themselves. If the peace officer is considered a supervisor, they may act in the capacity of a supervisor for the purposes of the request.ACTIVE
749
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3401(a)(a) Upon the supervisor concluding the supervisor request, the relevant detainment timer shall resume.ACTIVE
750
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3402No detainment timer shall apply if a person is being detained for the purposes of executing a warrant. Upon the warrant being executed, 4 M.S.C. 5 § 3203 shall apply.ACTIVE
751
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3403No detainment timer shall apply if a person is being detained for the purposes of being transported pursuant to State law.ACTIVE
752
753
SUBCHAPTER V. PERSON NOT PRESENT
754
755
4 M.S.C. 5 § 3501If a person does not verbally speak or otherwise indicate their presence for more than five (5) minutes, any relevant detainment shall end and the peace officer conducting the detainment shall either arrest or release the detained person.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER III. DEFINITIONS
777
778
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4301The term “firearm” shall refer to the definition prescribed by 4 M.S.C. 5 § 6101(a).
ACTIVE
779
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4302“Dispensed firearm” shall be defined as;ACTIVE
780
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4302(a)(a) Any firearm which is made available to a person through an equipment dispenser device of which the ability to dispense such a firearm is made available through employment or otherwise similar status within an authorized organization. This definition shall include though not be limited to firearms provided by government departments, agencies, or otherwise authorized authorities. ACTIVE
781
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4303The term “automatic firearm” shall be defined as;
ACTIVE
782
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4303(a)(a) Any self-loading firearm capable of continuously firing projectiles when the trigger mechanism is activated. ACTIVE
783
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4303(b)(b) Any self-loading firearm capable of firing multiple projectiles per a single activation of the trigger mechanism. ACTIVE
784
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4304The term “firearm modification” shall be defined as;ACTIVE
785
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4304(a)(a) Any component, attachment, or accessory designed or used to alter or enhance the functionality, performance, or characteristics of a weapon from its original manufactured state, including but not limited to devices affecting rate of fire, accuracy, caliber, or concealability. ACTIVE
786
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4304(b)(b) Any physical modification of the mechanical or external components of a firearm from its original manufactured state. ACTIVE
787
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4304(c)(c) This definition shall include though not be limited to removable devices such as weapon optics, barrel attachments, and otherwise similar devices.ACTIVE
788
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4305The term “Licensed Vender” shall be defined as;
ACTIVE
789
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4305(a)(a) Any individual person(s), organizations, private institutions or otherwise stores licensed to operate and participate in the trade and or sale of firearms,ACTIVE
790
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4306The term “Illicit Vender” shall be defined as;ACTIVE
791
4 M.S.C. 5 § 4306(a)(a) Any individual person(s), organizations, private institutions or otherwise stores which participate in the trade and or sale of firearms without being licensed to do so.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER II. WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTIONS
873
874
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5201A “Whistleblower” shall be defined as a person who discloses information protected by a court order, nondisclosure agreement, state secrecy, or otherwise protected as permitted under this subchapter.ACTIVE
875
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5202WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION. A whistleblower shall have the right to disclose information that is not otherwise publicly accessible, without threat of legal action, retaliation, or penalty, if the disclosure is made in good faith and based on a reasonable belief that one or more of the following conditions exists:ACTIVE
876
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5202(a)(a) A reasonable threat to public security or safety.ACTIVE
877
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5202(b)(b) Abuse by an authority.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 5202(d)(d) Gross mismanagement.ACTIVE
