SUBCHAPTER III. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION
895
896
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5301DEFINITIONS. A “State Agency” shall be defined as any government agency or department in the executive, legislative or judicial branch of the government.ACTIVE
897
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5302A “FOIA requester” shall be defined as a resident of the State of Mayflower who is requesting materials as permitted under this act.ACTIVE
898
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5303A “FOIA officer” or “Freedom of Information Access Officer” shall be defined as an employee of a State Agency who is responsible for responding to FOIA requests.ACTIVE
899
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5304A “Whistleblower” shall be defined as a person who discloses information protected by a court order, nondisclosure agreement or state secrecy as permitted under this act.ACTIVE
900
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305FREEDOM OF INFORMATION REQUESTS. Residents of the State of Mayflower have the right to request access to any record or information of a state agency, except where it is exempted as:ACTIVE
901
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(a)(a) The file(s) are classified for the defence, security, or foreign policy of the state and the file(s) as a whole fall under a classification level as designated under Title 4, Chapter I, Subchapter II of the Mayflower State Code.ACTIVE
902
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(b)(b) The file(s) are trade secrets or confidential business records.ACTIVE
903
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(c)(c) The file(s) relate to personnel records, unless it is the personnel records of the FOIA requester.ACTIVE
904
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(d)(d) The file(s) relates to law enforcement records, operations, processes, information, techniques, or would deprive a person of the right to a fair trial, or reveal the identity of a confidential informant.ACTIVE
905
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(e)(e) The file(s) relate to a State Agency academy or education.ACTIVE
906
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5305(f)(f) The file(s) relate to foreign or domestic intelligence or counterintelligence.ACTIVE
907
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5306If the file(s) that a FOIA requester is asking for does not exist, then the FOIA officer must notify the FOIA requester of such.ACTIVE
908
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5307If the request submitted by the FOIA requester is too broad, then the FOIA officer may deny the request and notify the FOIA requester of such.ACTIVE
909
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5308If file(s) requested by a FOIA requester contains lines, pages, portions, or media which is deemed to fall under a classification level as designated under Title 4, Chapter I, Subchapter II of the Mayflower State Code, then the FOIA officer must make a copy of the original file(s) and redact such information from the file(s), but not delete it, before submitting it to the FOIA requester where the reason for the redactions are clearly labelled.ACTIVE
910
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5309When submitting a FOIA, the FOIA requester must ensure that they:ACTIVE
911
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5309(a)(a) Describe in as much detail as possible the file(s) being requested.ACTIVE
912
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5309(b)(b) Inform the State Agency of the purpose of the request.ACTIVE
913
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5310Every state agency shall employ a Freedom of Information Access Officer.ACTIVE
914
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5310(a)(a) This employee may be a civilian employee.ACTIVE
915
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5310(b)(b) The department head of a State Agency shall be assumed to be the FOIA Officer should the role not be delegated to another individual.ACTIVE
916
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5311The FOIA Officer shall be responsible for:ACTIVE
917
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5311(a)(a) Handling FOIA requestsACTIVE
918
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5311(b)(b) Managing and publishing a publicly accessible FOIA request form for the state agency for which they are employed.ACTIVE
919
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5311(c)(c) Managing a database that contains all file(s) related to the State Agency for which they are employed.ACTIVE
920
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5311(d)(d) Further redacting file(s) which are requested by a FOIA requester so that it may be publicly viewable.ACTIVE
921
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312The Freedom of Information Access Officer must respond to a FOIA Requester within 4 days of a FOIA request and:ACTIVE
922
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312(a)(a) Provide the FOIA requester with the requested informationACTIVE
923
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312(b)(b) Partially provide the FOIA requester with the requested information, and inform the FOIA requester that the remainder of the request is exempted from the request, and cite the exemption.ACTIVE
924
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312(c)(c) Inform the FOIA requester that their request will not be fulfilled due to falling under an exemption, and cite the exemption.ACTIVE
925
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312(d)(d) Inform the FOIA requester that the Freedom of Information Access Officer requires additional time to fulfil the request, and that it will be fulfilled within the next 3 days.ACTIVE
926
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5312(e)(e) Request that the FOIA requester further clarifies their request. Should this need arise, the time requirement shall reset upon the FOIA requester clarifying their request, or shall be denied should the FOIA requester not respond within 24 hours of the Freedom of Information Access Officer requesting the clarification.ACTIVE
927
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5313FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACCESS. Should a State Agency fail to respond to a FOIA request, then the FOIA requester may petition a court to order the release of the file(s) within 24 hours, unless the file(s) fall under an aforementioned exemption.ACTIVE
928
4 M.S.C. 5 § 5314ENFORCEMENT. Should a State Agency fail to respond to a court order, then the FOIA officer shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1304 “Misconduct”.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 5 § 7101“Burn Permit” shall refer to a certification held by a law enforcement officer, issued by a County Fire Chief, that allows for the destruction of civilian vehicles that meet detailed requirements.
ACTIVE
989
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7102“Burn” shall refer to the action taken by a law enforcement officer in exploding a vehicle in a safe and controlled manner.
ACTIVE
990
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7103“Special Vehicle” shall refer to a vehicle not accessible for purchase by all members of the public, that is issued by Community Oversight for the usage of an organization and is only possible to be spawned by members of such an organization.
ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER II. FIRE MARSHAL'S OFFICE
993
994
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7201Every County Fire Department shall establish a Fire Marshal’s Office, led by the County Fire Marshal who shall be an individual appointed by and deemed competent by the County Fire Chief.
ACTIVE
995
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202The Fire Marshal’s Office shall be split into divisions and ranks as the County Fire Marshal sees fit, but shall be generally tasked with:
ACTIVE
996
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202(a)(a) Writing, updating and releasing a Law Enforcement Burn Guide, which shall contain all safety and regulatory information pertaining to the obtaining of Burn Permits and the carrying out of a Burn.ACTIVE
997
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202(b)(b) Writing and reviewing Burn Permit Assessments, which shall be examinations testing all aspects of carrying out Burns and examining information listed in the Burn Guide.ACTIVE
998
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202(c)(c) Reviewing reports of misconduct pertaining to Burns/violations of the Burn Guide carried out by law enforcement officers.ACTIVE
999
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202(d)(d) Carrying out investigations into potential misconduct pertaining to Burns/violations of the Burn Guide carried out by law enforcement officers.ACTIVE
1000
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7202(e)(e) Issuing, suspending and revoking Burn Permits.ACTIVE
1001
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7203All actions taken by the Fire Marshal’s Office shall be open to review by the County Fire Chief, who may override any decisions made with reasonable basis and explanation.
ACTIVE
1002
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7204The County Fire Chief shall have the liberty to appoint and remove the County Fire Marshal in accordance with state laws regarding employment rights, and the County Fire Marshal shall be treated as any subordinate command employee.
ACTIVE
1003
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7205The Burn Assessment and Burn Guide shall include but are not limited to including the following information:
ACTIVE
1004
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7205(a)(a) All safety regulations ensuring the lack of harm towards others.ACTIVE
1005
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7205(b)(b) All safety regulations ensuring the lack of chain reaction explosions.ACTIVE
1006
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7205(c)(c) Legal premises allowing for a vehicle to be burnt.ACTIVE
1007
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7205(d)(d) Allowed properties for Burns to be carried out on.ACTIVE
1008

SUBCHAPTER III. BURN PERMIT STATUSES
1010
1011
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7301All law enforcement officers who wish to carry out Burns must hold an active Burn Permit Certification, issued by the County Fire Marshal’s Office.
ACTIVE
1012
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7302All law enforcement officers without prior history of misconduct relating to Burns shall be eligible for a Burn Permit, and must achieve 85% (eighty five percent) or higher in the Burn Permit Assessment.ACTIVE
1013
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7303The County Fire Marshal’s Office shall be obliged to open the Burn Permit Assessment indefinitely throughout all times of the year and regularly mark responses, releasing results and issuing Burn Permits every 2 (two) weeks or less.
ACTIVE
1014
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7304The County Fire Marshal’s Office shall be obliged to release and regularly review a forum for members of the public to report misconduct pertaining to Burns, and shall be obliged to investigate each report to the fullest.ACTIVE
1015
4 M.S.C. 5 § 7305The County Fire Marshal’s Office shall reserve the right to blacklist, revoke or suspend Burn Permits from law enforcement officers found to be in violation of the Burn Guide and other regulations clearly set by the Fire Marshal’s Office. The severity of the administrative action shall be based on the severity of the misconduct committed, however shall be to the discretion of the Fire Marshal’s Office.

4 M.S.C. 6 § 1202A proprietary private security employer shall be defined as a person who has one or more employees who provide security services for the employer and only the employer. A person who employs proprietary security guards pursuant to this definition at more than one location owned and operated by the employer shall still be considered a single employer.
ACTIVE
1111
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1203A security guard or security officer shall be defined as an employee of a private patrol operator who is licensed to and performs the duties of a private patrol operator in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter.
ACTIVE
1112
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1204A private patrol operator and or any other variation thereof shall be defined as a person and or organization, who, for any consideration whatsoever; agrees to furnish, or furnishes a security officer or guard, or other person to protect persons or property to prevent the theft, loss, embezzlement, or concealment of any goods, merchandise, money, or property of any kind; or performs the service of a security officer or guard for any of these purposes.

SUBCHAPTER III. DEPARTMENT OF STATE OVERSIGHT AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1115
1116
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1301The Department of State shall form a commission responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this Chapter. Furthermore this commission shall be uniquely responsible for the issuance, suspension, and revocation of security licenses in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.
ACTIVE
1117
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1302The Department of State shall draft, maintain and issue an examination of which the passing of shall be required for an individual to acquire a security license from the Department of State.
ACTIVE
1118
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1303The Department of State shall be provided a document titled the “Power to Arrest Training Manual,” which shall detail the provisions of this Chapter in an attempt to educate those seeking a security license from the Department of State. Using this document, the State Department shall either directly be responsible for the administration of the required curriculum or permit a registered educational institution to do so on behalf of the State. ACTIVE
1119
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304The Commission which the State Department designates to oversee the management of security license shall be permitted to modify license status only in the following situations:ACTIVE
1120
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(a)(a) A security license may be issued only if an individual has completed the required training process and passed the required examination, or otherwise has an exemption provided by this Chapter.ACTIVE
1121
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(b)(b) A security license may be suspended if the holder has failed to maintain citizenship status, or is the subject of official investigation by the State Department or the investigative unit of any law enforcement agency, or representative of the Department of Justice.ACTIVE
1122
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c)(c) For a security license to be revoked, the specific license holder must meet one the following criteria:ACTIVE
1123
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c)(i)(i) Previous active conviction in a court of law of any criminal offense other than an infraction.ACTIVE
1124
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c)(ii)(ii) Four in total or more active misdemeanor records and/or three in total or more active felony records, of which are not actively being disputed or in the process to do so through a court of law.ACTIVE
1125
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c)(iii)(iii) Conviction by a court of a felony violation or multiple (or consecutive) violations of state law within twenty-four (24) hours.ACTIVE
1126
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c)(iv)(iv) Repeated, or serious violation of the Security Services Act or any other private security regulation promulgated by the Department of State.ACTIVE
1127
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(d)(d) A security license may be suspended as a result of an investigation conducted by the Department of State for a time specified in the investigation report that does not exceed thirty (30) days.ACTIVE
1128
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(d)(i)(i) A security license may be suspended for the duration of a criminal trial in which the holder is charged with any criminal offense other than an infraction.ACTIVE
1129
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1305An individual applicant may not be issued a security license by the State Department if the applicant meets one of the criterion found within 4 M.S.C. 6 § 1304(c) that would normally warrant a license revocation.ACTIVE
1130
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1306A license may not be issued to an applicant without active residency.ACTIVE
1131
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1307The State Department shall be permitted to, on an individual basis, exempt an applicant from the required training and examination if the applicant is an active peace officer as defined by the State code, or an otherwise honorably discharged person which previously held such a position.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER V. REGULATIONS AND EXEMPTIONS
1140
1141
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501An individual representing the organization of which they are employed and acting in the capacity of a security officer or proprietary security guard shall be required to display a unique uniform compliant with this Chapter designated by their employer.ACTIVE
1142
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501(a)(a) For the purpose of this code, a uniform shall be considered compliant if it aligns with all of the following components:ACTIVE
1143
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501(a)(i)(i) A uniform which bears at least one patch, badge, ID, logo, or otherwise emblem visible at all times clearly identifying the employing company.ACTIVE
1144
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501(a)(ii)(ii) Authorized officers may perform duties regulated under this chapter in 'non uniformed' status on a limited special assignment basis, and only when duty circumstances or special requirements of the client necessitate such dress. Licensees who are performing bodyguard or executive protection services may choose to carry their authorized equipment while in non uniformed status as needed in the conduct of such services.ACTIVE
1145
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501(a)(iii)(iii) The uniform may not bear the insignia of any other organization, agency, or any otherwise group which is not directly affiliated with the organization which uses such a uniform.REPEALED
1146
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1501(b)(b) Security officers and or proprietary security guards which fail to comply with the uniform mandate shall not receive any protection or exemption by the provisions of this act.ACTIVE
1147
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1502A licensed private security officer or licensed proprietary security guard which has in their possession a valid firearms license shall be permitted to carry and display in public and/or in a restricted or otherwise firearms freezone, if the aforementioned restricted or otherwise firearms freezone is within the reasonable scope of their duties, a loaded firearm.ACTIVE
1148
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1503A licensed security officer shall be permitted to carry on their person and utilize, when on duty and conducting official security duties, and in accordance with provisions of State law the following articles of equipment and their respective ammunition or otherwise essential components; extendable, fixed and straight batons, stun guns or taser devices, pepper-spray or other similar chemical self-defense items, encrypted handheld radios, fixed or chain connected handcuffs; and the Bennetti 17 pistol.ACTIVE
1149
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1504A private security officer specifically directed to do so by an on-duty peace officer as defined by the State Code may be permitted to assist in the detainment, arrest, or capture of a criminal wrongdoer; however, security officers shall never, under any circumstances, be authorized to engage or assist directly or indirectly, in a vehicular pursuit. Private security officers may be permitted to close or block public roadways if authorized to do so by an on-duty supervisor of a law enforcement agency to ensure public safety during significant emergencies.ACTIVE
1150
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1505A security officer may only protect an asset, property or person when the security entity they are employed by has a contract or signed agreement to protect such asset, property or person and said security officer is authorized by his employer to provide such protective services.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER VI. POWER TO ARREST; AUTHORITY TO ARREST
1153
1154
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1601For the purposes of this Subchapter, the term “authorized officer” shall be defined as a security officer, or proprietary security guard.ACTIVE
1155
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1602Peace officers defined by the State code discharging the authority of arrest on behalf of the State involved in the secondary duty of an authorized officer shall be exempt from the provisions of this Subchapter.
ACTIVE
1156
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1603An authorized officer shall be permitted to hold an individual within their custody only under the following conditions:
ACTIVE
1157
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1603(a)(a) For an codified offense of the State code punishable by arrest committed or attempted within the presence of an authorized officer. ACTIVE
1158
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1603(b)(b) For a codified felony offense of the State code which the authorized officer has evidence of such an offense although not not committed within their presence. ACTIVE
1159
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1603(c)(c) When ordered to do so by a peace officer as defined by the State code. Such a detention shall be considered an action on behalf of the peace officer rather than the authorized officer.ACTIVE
1160
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1604Upon effecting an arrest, an authorized officer shall be required to contact a peace officer within a reasonable timeframe to take custody of the violator and provide the peace officer with evidence of the offense which the individual was arrested for.ACTIVE
1161
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1605An authorized officer shall have the sole authority to conduct an arrest with reasonable and plausible cause to do so. Upon affecting an arrest a authorized officer may not release a violator unless ordered to do so by a peace officer or due to emergent circumstances. Unlike a peace officer, an authorized officer shall not be permitted to detain a person for investigative purposes, and as such may only hold a person within their custody to effect an arrest. ACTIVE
1162
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1606Upon an arrest being effected, an authorized officer must immediately inform the individual which is within their custody of the crime which they are being arrested for, and their authority to do so.ACTIVE
1163
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1607An authorized officer attempting to effect an arrest may utilize handcuffs or similar devices to hold an individual within their custody. Furthermore authorized officers shall be permitted to use a reasonable amount of force to prevent the evasion, or resistance of such an arrest. ACTIVE
1164
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1608An authorized officer may transit an arrested individual within their custody to a holding room or hold them within a marked security vehicle whilst awaiting peace officer arrival.ACTIVE
1165
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1609An authorized officer may search the person of an arrested individual though may only remove weapons, and must transfer seized items to a peace officer upon arrival. Additionally an authorized officer may search the person of any individual which consents to such a search.ACTIVE
1166
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1610The authority granted under 4 M.S.C. 6 § 1603 (a) and (b) shall only be exercised under the following conditions:ACTIVE
1167
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1610(a)(a) The authorized officer is actively engaged in the protection of a contracted property, person, or asset, and is either on, in, or in the immediate vicinity of that property, person, or asset; orACTIVE
1168
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1610(b)(b) When not in the immediate vicinity of a property, person, or asset they are contracted and authorized to protect, but during exigent circumstances to protect human life. This subsection shall not be construed to allow authorized officers to patrol or seek out criminal wrongdoers not within the scope of their official security duties to protect a contracted property, asset, or person.ACTIVE
1169

SUBCHAPTER VII. ENFORCEMENT
1171
1172
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1701Any individual who without a license attempts to, or operates a private patrol operator service shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1406 “Unlawful Operation of a Business” and/or 1 M.S.C. § 1318 “Impersonation of a Private Security Officer” if applicable.ACTIVE
1173
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1702Any private patrol operator which knowingly employs an individual without a security license as a security officer within their organization shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1406 “Unlawful Operation of a Business.“ACTIVE
1174
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1703Any individual which acts in the capacity of a security officer without having in their possession an active security license shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 1318 “Impersonation of a Private Security Officer."ACTIVE
1175
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1704A proprietary security guard which carries on their person a firearm whilst representing the proprietary security employer and does not have in their possession an active security license shall be guilty of 1 M.S.C. § 6102 “Unlicensed Possession of a Firearm.”ACTIVE
1176
4 M.S.C. 6 § 1705Any individual which attempts to exercise the exemptions or authority of a security officer, proprietary security guard, or private patrol operator without total compliance with the provisions of this Chapter shall receive no exemption or protection from liability which is found therein.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER IV. REGULATION OF CASINOS

4 M.S.C. 6 § 2401CASINO FINANCIALS. This chapter/Subchapter of the State Code is established to provide laws pertaining to the oversight, regulation, fairness, transparency, and accountability of Casino and Online Games websites and operations run within, or operating within, the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
1212
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2402Businesses conducting gambling or casino like operations, herein “Casino” must be responsible for transparency with their financials, and shall be obligated to prepare and publicly announce the following Financial Statements every fiscal quarter:ACTIVE
1213
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2402(a)(a) A Statement of Cash Flows.ACTIVE
1214

1217
4 M.S.C. x § 2402(d)(i)(i) This shall be a ledger containing the record of any cash disbursement made as a donation, payment, or any other transfer of funds from the business to a third party within that financial quarter.ACTIVE
1218
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2403A Casino may not permit an individual user to withdraw more than $7,000,000 of their deposits/winnings at the casino in a 7 day period.ACTIVE
1219
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2404CONSUMER PROTECTIONS. Businesses conducting casino-like operations must be responsible for listing odds for all games. Whether it is in percentile or fraction format, the odds for all games. The odds must be displayed in a manner that a reasonable person would be able to properly read from a reasonable distance.ACTIVE
1220
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2405Casinos must disclose publicly and visibly any and all games in which the “house” or the business is favored to win the game, or in other words, where the person has a 49% chance or less to win.ACTIVE
1221
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2406Casinos must publicly report changes in odds, gameplay, or any other mechanic that may alter the experience of the casino in any way when the changes are made and in a monthly report. If there is no alteration as described above, a monthly report need not be published.ACTIVE
1222
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2407Any advertisement or promotion for Casinos must provide, in visible font and coloring that a reasonable person can see from a reasonable distance, a support website for chronic gambling addictions.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER VI. FINANCIAL CRIMES
1234
1235
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2601A new Chapter within the Mayflower Criminal Code shall be created: “Financial Crimes."ACTIVE
1236
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2602All crimes within Section IV of the Financial Reporting and Crimes Act shall be classified as Financial Crimes. ACTIVE
1237
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2603The following crimes shall be created and codified within the Mayflower Criminal Code:ACTIVE
1238
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2604“Bank Robbery” shall be created and defined as follows:
ACTIVE
1239
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2604(a)(a) Any person whether by force or intimidation, that takes any property or money in the care, custody, control, etc. of any bank, credit union, or savings and loan institution.ACTIVE
1240
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2604(b)(b) Shall be guilty of a felony and sentenced to 30 minutes in prison.ACTIVE
1241
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2604(c)(c) This statue shall be set to active within the Mayflower Criminal Code.ACTIVE
1242
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605“Money Laundering” shall be created and defined as follows:
ACTIVE
1243
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605(a)(a) Any person, knowing that the property involved in a financial transaction represents the proceeds of some form of unlawful activity, conducts or attempts to conduct such a financial transaction which in fact involves the proceeds of unlawful activity with the intent to promote the carrying on of specified unlawful activity; or knowing that the transaction is designed in whole or in part;ACTIVE
1244
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605(a)(i)(i) to conceal or disguise the nature, the location, the source, the ownership, or the control of the proceeds of specified unlawful activity; orACTIVE
1245
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605(a)(ii)(ii) to avoid a transaction reporting requirement under Local, State or Federal law;ACTIVE
1246
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605(b)(b) Shall be guilty of a felony and sentenced to 30 minutes in prison and/or face a fine of not more than $5,000 or twice the value of the property involved in the transaction, whichever is greater. ACTIVE
1247
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2605(c)(c) This statue shall be set to active within the Mayflower Criminal Code.ACTIVE
1248
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2606“Embezzlement” shall be created and defined as follows:
ACTIVE
1249
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2606(a)(a) A person who shall, having lawful custody of property not his or her own, appropriate the same to his or her own use, with intent to deprive the owner thereof; ACTIVE
1250
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2606(b)(b) Shall be guilty of a felony and sentenced to 50 minutes in prison and/or face a fine of not more than $5,000 or twice the value of the property involved in the transaction, whichever is greater. ACTIVE
1251
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2606(c)(c) This statue shall be set to By Conviction within the Mayflower Criminal Code.ACTIVE
1252
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2607“Counterfeiting” shall be created and defined as follows:
ACTIVE
1253
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2607(a)(a) Any person, with intent to defraud, falsely makes, forges, counterfeits, or alters any obligation or other security of the State of Mayflower or Union of Columbia; ACTIVE
1254
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2607(b)(b) Shall be guilty of a felony and sentenced to 120 minutes in prison.ACTIVE
1255
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2607(c)(c) This statue shall be set to By Conviction within the Mayflower Criminal Code.ACTIVE
1256
4 M.S.C. 6 § 26081 M.S.C. § 1301 “Bribery” shall be reclassified as a Financial Crime.ACTIVE
1257
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2609“Loan Sharking” shall be added and defined as follows: Any Lender who provides a loan not in accordance with Usury Laws or Loan Prohibitions shall be guilty of a felony and sentenced to 25 minutes in prison and/or face a fine of not more than $20,000 or twice the value of the loan, whichever is greater.ACTIVE
1258
4 M.S.C. 6 § 2610Commercial instrument falsification in the second degree’ shall be defined as follows: Any person who, with intent to defraud, knowingly falsifies, alters, or forges any commercial instrument shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.ACTIVE

CHAPTER III. LOAN SERVICES
1261
1262
1263
SUBCHAPTER I. DEFINITIONS; SHORT TITLE
1264
1265
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3101A “Borrower” shall be defined as a person or business who is loaned money from a Lender.ACTIVE
1266
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3102A “Lender” shall be defined as a business which loans money to a Borrower.ACTIVE
1267
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3103A “loan” shall be defined as a sum of money or other asset provided by a Lender to a Borrower under an agreement that it will be repaid in the future, typically with interest as compensation for the use of the funds.ACTIVE
1268
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3104An “interest rate” shall be defined as “the percentage charged or paid on the principal amount of a loan or deposit, calculated over a specified period, as agreed between the Lender and Borrower or deposit holder and institution.”ACTIVE
1269
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3105A “collateral” shall be defined as an asset or property offered by a Borrower to be given to the Lender should the Borrower fail to repay the loan.ACTIVE
1270
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3106This chapter may be cited as the "Loan Shark Extinction Act."ACTIVE
1271
1272
SUBCHAPTER II. LOAN REQUIREMENTS
1273
1274
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3201A Lender must have the loan readily available to the Borrower upon effect of the loan.ACTIVE
1275
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3202The Borrower must repay the loan and in full to the Lender by the conclusion of the loan.ACTIVE
1276
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3203A Lender may request collateral from a Borrower as a security against a loan.ACTIVE
1277
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3203(a)(a) The collateral must be agreed in writing in the same document the loan is signed on.ACTIVE
1278
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3203(b)(b) Should the Borrower fail to repay the loan, the collateral shall automatically be transferred to the ownership of the Lender.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER III. USURY LAWS
1281
1282
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3301A loan may only be offered by a Lender where the Borrower can repay the loan in whole, or at an agreed rate or repayment of weekly, fortnightly, monthly, once every two months, quarterly, once every 6 months, or yearly.ACTIVE
1283
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3302An interest rate may not be larger than:ACTIVE
1284
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3302(a)(a) 40% of a principle where the loan rate of repayment is of weekly or fortnightly recurrence.ACTIVE
1285
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3302(b)(b) 35% of a principle where the loan rate of repayment is monthly, once every two months, or quarterly.ACTIVE
1286
4 M.S.C. 6 § 3302(c)(c) 30% of a principle where the loan rate of repayment is once every 6 months, or yearly.ACTIVE

1567

SUBCHAPTER VI. SUSPENSION
1575
1576
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1601Suspension shall refer to the prevention of a person from executing their duties and collecting pay for either a set period of time or indefinitely.ACTIVE
1577
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602Administrative leave shall be the indefinite suspension pending an investigation. A person may only be put on administrative leave for allegations which, if taken as true, would warrant a general discharge or dishonorable discharge.ACTIVE
1578
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(a)(a) A person may only be on administrative leave for no longer than ten (10) days; however, a person may be put on administrative leave for longer if there is a criminal investigation supplemented by order from the Department of Justice for the person to be placed on administrative leave.ACTIVE
1579
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(b)(b) Administrative leave may be used in extreme cases where the probable punishment of suspension – however, the length of suspension must have the days on administrative leave subtracted from it.ACTIVE
1580
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(c)(c) Administrative leave may only be used if there is a pending misconduct investigation or criminal investigation.ACTIVE
1581
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d)(d) Any administrative leave imposed as a result of a pending misconduct investigation or criminal investigation shall last up to thirty (30) days or until the conclusion of the investigation, whichever occurs first.ACTIVE
1582
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d)(i)(i) If, upon conclusion of a misconduct or criminal investigation, probable cause of a criminal violation is found and the matter is pending review for criminal charges by the Department of Justice, the administrative leave imposed under 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d) may be extended for a period not to exceed seven (7) additional days. Such extension shall not be subject to the thirty (30) day limit prescribed in 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d).ACTIVE
1583
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(e)(e) Any administrative leave extended pursuant to 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d)(i) may be further extended for an indefinite period if, during the seven (7) day extension, criminal charges are formally filed. In such cases, administrative leave shall continue until the conclusion of the subsequent criminal matter.ACTIVE
1584
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1603There shall be no review by an administrative court of the placement of someone on administrative leave unless—
ACTIVE
1585
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1603(a)(a) the placement was not by an internal affairs entity, command entity;ACTIVE
1586
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1603(b)(b) the suspension has gone on longer than allowed under 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(a); orACTIVE
1587
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1603(c)(c) the administrative leave extended under 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d), 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(d)(i), or 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1602(e) exceeds its respective limitations without criminal filing or conclusion of the investigation.ACTIVE
1588
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1604Involuntary suspension shall refer to a suspension as specified in 4 M.S.C. 7 § 1601 for a period of time no longer than seven (7) days.ACTIVE
1589
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1605A person may be suspended for a violation of the policy, rule, or procedure notwithstanding the existence of or there the results of an internal investigation for no longer than three (3) days.
ACTIVE
1590
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1606A person may only be suspended for greater than three (3) days upon recommendation and finding of fact from a bona fide misconduct investigation.
ACTIVE
1591
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1607It is unlawful to arbitrarily, or without due observance of law, issue a suspension demerit.
ACTIVE
1592
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1608The Attorney General shall serve as the designated enforcer of 4 M.S.C. 7 §§ 1602(d), 1602(d)(i), 1602(e), 1603(a), 1603(b), and 1603(c).ACTIVE
1593
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1609Any department, agency, or official in violation of the procedures prescribed in either 4 M.S.C. 7 §§ 1602(d), 1602(d)(i), 1602(e), 1603(a), 1603(b), or 1603(c) may be subject to administrative or civil action under 4 M.S.C. 7 § 2601 et seq.ACTIVE

SUBCHAPTER VIII. ARBITRARY PUNISHMENT PROHIBITED
1601
1602
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801Arbitrary punishment is defined as:ACTIVE
1603
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801(a)(a) punishment that has no backing in regulation, policy, or law; ACTIVE
1604
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801(b)(b) punishment whose policy, law, or regulation prescribing it is ambiguous, or unclear, or a violation of a constitutional right or privilege or statutory enactment; ACTIVE
1605
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801(c)(c) punishment with no factual backing; ACTIVE
1606
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801(d)(d) punishment outside and beyond what is explicitly prescribed in policy; orACTIVE
1607
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1801(e)(e) punishment that takes no accounting of mitigating factors, circumstances, or liabilities.ACTIVE
1608
4 M.S.C. 7 § 1802Arbitrary punishment is prohibited.

SUBCHAPTER IV. LIMITS OF EMPLOYMENT IN CERTAIN CAPACITIES
1648
1649
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2401The rank at which a staff position begins shall be clearly defined by a department through their policy.ACTIVE
1650
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2402If a department does not specify a staff position then it shall be considered that they have no staff positions for the purposes of this Subchapter and Chapter.
ACTIVE
1651
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2403A command position is a position or rank within a department’s leadership such as:ACTIVE
1652
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2403(a)(a) the department head, or director, or superintendent of the department; ACTIVE
1653
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2403(b)(b) the designated successor, by policy or statutorily, to the department head, director, or superintendent of the department; orACTIVE
1654
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2403(c)(c) a staff assistant, vice, or deputy to either the successor thereto or the department head, director, or superintendent of the department.ACTIVE
1655
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2404No person shall be in more than one primary department.ACTIVE
1656
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2405No person shall be in more than two secondary departments unless they are not employed in a primary department, in which case they may be in one additional secondary department.ACTIVE
1657
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2406A person may be employed in both a secondary and primary department so long as they never exceed the defined limits.ACTIVE
1658
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2407A person may be in as many civil service positions as they so choose, and as long as they can affirmatively meet the standards and activity requirements of such civil service positions. ACTIVE
1659
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2408Agencies and departments may promulgate additional rules, policies, or procedures which would otherwise extend these provisions to disallow employment in either a primary or secondary.ACTIVE
1660
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2409No person shall hold more than two staff positions in both a primary or secondary agency at one time.ACTIVE
1661
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2410No person who holds a command position in a primary or secondary agency may hold a staff position in any primary or secondary agency.
ACTIVE
1662
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2411No person shall be grandfathered into any role or position by the effectuation of this legislation, and that the enforcement of this section shall happen immediately after the effective date of this legislation.
INACTIVE
1663
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2412The courts shall have no jurisdiction to hear a civil action based on a violation of this Chapter, and the enforcement of this Chapter shall be left solely up to the designated enforcer.ACTIVE
1664
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2413This subchapter does not apply to individuals who would otherwise be in violation of its provisions, provided they were employed before the enactment of this act and have not experienced any change in their public employment status, including leaving or joining any department, whether voluntarily or through lawful termination or reassignment. If any such change in public employment occurs, the individual will no longer qualify for this exemption and must fully comply with the provisions of this Subchapter. The exempted individual must also provide valid documentation of their original public employment to the Attorney General or his designee upon request.ACTIVE
1665

1668

SUBCHAPTER V. MERIT SYSTEM
1671
1672
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501The principles of the merit system shall be as follows:ACTIVE
1673
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(a)(a) Recruitment should be from qualified individuals from appropriate sources in an endeavor to achieve a work force from all segments of society, and selection and advancement should be determined solely on the basis of relative ability, knowledge and skills, after fair and open competition which assures that all receive equal opportunity.ACTIVE
1674
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(b)(b) All employees and applicants for employment should receive fair and equitable treatment in all aspects of personnel management without regard to political affiliation, race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, or handicapping condition, and with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights.ACTIVE
1675
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(c)(c) All employees should maintain high standards of integrity, conduct, and concern for the public interest.ACTIVE
1676
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(d)(d) The State workforce should be used efficiently and effectively.ACTIVE
1677
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(e)(e) Employees should be retained on the basis of adequacy of their performance, inadequate performance should be corrected, and employees should be separated who cannot or will not improve their performance to meet required standards.ACTIVE
1678
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(f)(f) Employees should be provided effective education and training in cases in which such education and training would result in better organizational and individual performance.ACTIVE
1679
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(g)(g) Employees should be—ACTIVE
1680
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(g)(i)(i) protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or coercion for political purposes; andACTIVE
1681
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2501(g)(ii)(ii) prohibited from using their official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or a nomination for election.ACTIVE
1682
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2502Employees should be protected against reprisal for the lawful disclosure of information which the employees reasonably believe evidences-- a violation of any law, rule, or regulation, or mismanagement, a gross waste of resources, an abuse of authority, or a substantial and specific danger to public safety.
ACTIVE
1683
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503The attributes of the merit system shall be as follows:ACTIVE
1684
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(a) When making decisions of employment or promotion, officials shall review the following attributes of merit:ACTIVE
1685
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(i)(i) logged patrol/work hours for the current cycle;ACTIVE
1686
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(ii)(ii) past performance in other departments;ACTIVE
1687
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(iii)(iii) abilities to work as a team and play well with others, which is affirmed by testimony of another leader or employee;ACTIVE
1688
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(iv)(iv) demonstration of sound judgment, which is affirmed by testimony of another leader;ACTIVE
1689
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(v)(v) demonstration of leadership qualities while holding a position in the State of Mayflower, which is affirmed by testimony of another leader or employee;ACTIVE
1690
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(vi)(vi) effort in the completion of an application, cover letter, or letter of interest;ACTIVE
1691
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(vii)(vii) scores on an accredited exam, if applicable;ACTIVE
1692
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(viii)(viii) commendations or written letters of recommendation; andACTIVE
1693
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2503(a)(ix)(ix) holding a valid accreditation, which may be required for the position.ACTIVE
1694
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2504Performance in another community or group shall not be used as a means to demonstrate the merit of an individual.ACTIVE
1695
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505When making a hiring decision officials can use the following attributes to discredit and demerit a hire:
ACTIVE
1696
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(a)(a) bad performance in another department or agency;ACTIVE
1697
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(b)(b) poor completion of an application, cover letter, or letter of interest;ACTIVE
1698
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(c)(c) poor accredited exam scores;ACTIVE
1699
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(d)(d) past disciplinary actions;ACTIVE
1700
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(e)(e) character defects which would bring harm to the health of the department or community;ACTIVE
1701
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(f)(f) failure to use discretion;ACTIVE
1702
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(g)(g) inability to gain a security clearance, other than not requiring it in the first place;ACTIVE
1703
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(h)(h) refusal to comply with regulations or lawful orders;ACTIVE
1704
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(i)(i) terrible activity in a previous department or agency; orACTIVE
1705
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2505(j)(j) no, or little experience within the State of Mayflower.ACTIVE
1706
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2506During the hiring process, an agency shall indicate all attributes of merit and demerit and subjectively, according to their own principles, weigh each application.
ACTIVE
1707
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2507A competitive hiring round shall be any hiring period where the number of spots to be taken in is clearly defined, publicly posted, and limited.ACTIVE
1708
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2507(a)(a) A department may not intake more than the number of applicants they have posted in a competitive hiring round.ACTIVE
1709
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2508A non-competitive hiring round shall be any hiring round where the number of spots is not clearly defined, publicly posted, and not limited.ACTIVE
1710
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2508(a)(a) If a person passes all preceding stages in a non-competitive hiring round, then they must be accepted as their outcome so long as this would not cause the department to exceed their allocated budget.ACTIVE
1711
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2509An application / character screening may only be denied for an attribute of demerit, and accepted for an attribute of merit. If they have neither then they shall be denied.ACTIVE
1712
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2510No individual may skip more than three (3) consecutive ranks from their current rank.ACTIVE
1713
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2510(a)(a) If any Department is found promoting someone over three (3) ranks, the Department of Justice shall investigate such Department for any findings of Nepotism and any level of Misconduct.ACTIVE
1714
4 M.S.C. 7 § 2510(b)(b) The Mayflower National Guard shall be exempt from paragraph 2510 of this subchapter.ACTIVE

4 M.S.C. 7 § 3401Administrative hearings have the following attributes:ACTIVE

1957
1958
4 M.S.C. 8 § 1201The department head of the Lander City Police Department may initiate an emergency lockdown of the State Capitol Building for no longer than 2 hours if there are credible concerns for its security.
ACTIVE
1959
4 M.S.C. 8 § 1201(a)(a) The Lander City Police Department must submit a public notice 5 minutes before it is enforced.ACTIVE
1960
4 M.S.C. 8 § 1201(b)(b) Persons that are not an on-duty peace officer or government official may not enter the State Capitol Building without the consent of an on-duty peace officer, member of the State Legislature, or the Governor.ACTIVE
1961
4 M.S.C. 8 § 1201(c)(c) Persons that enter the State Capitol Building without the aforementioned consent after a public notice has been given are liable to be arrested for trespass.ACTIVE
1962
4 M.S.C. 8 § 1201(d)(d) After a lockdown is lifted, the Lander City Police Department must publish a report detailing the start and end time and date of the lockdown, purpose of the lockdown, what occurred during the lockdown, and the result of the lockdown within three days.ACTIVE
